Authors:
Kristian Persson Hodén, Xinyi Hu, Anna Asman, Zhen Liao,
Fredrik Dölfors, Christina Dixelius
Title:
Phytophthora infestans miRNA facilitates potato
infection
Abstract:
The late blight disease of potato (Solanum tuberosum, St)
and tomato (S. lycopersicum) incited by the oomycete Phytophthora
infestans (Pi) causes global annual losses estimated to  12 billions1.
P. infestans is well-known for having a genome enriched of genes coding
for effector proteins that promote plant infection by secretion into the
apoplastic and cytoplasmic spaces of the host tissue2,3. These virulence
genes are predominantly located among repeat sequences, explaining the
rapid adaptation potential of this pathogen. Here, we used an Ago1-GFP
P. infestans strain4 to analyze small RNA (sRNA) associated events
during potato infection. We show extensive targeting of potato and
pathogen-derived sRNAs to a large number of genes, including 206
resistance (R) genes in the host genome. Intriguingly, the single miRNA
encoded by P. infestans (miR8788) was found to target a lipase-like
membrane protein-encoding gene StLL1 whose suppression promotes pathogen
growth. miR8788 seems to be an ancient molecule, tracing back to strains
from 1846, which highlights its role in abating the defense machinery.
That P. infestans exploit its sRNA as a new type of effector adds
another level to the already challenging crop protection efforts to this
devastating pathogen.
